hints_html:
We write down what it means for \(f\) to be continuous. This is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x\rightarrow t^-} f(x) &= \lim_{x\rightarrow t^+} f(x)\\ e^{-t}&=2(t+1)\end{aligned}\]

In order for our function to be continuous, we need a solution to the above equation. Now we can apply the hint in the problem to use the intermediate value theorem.

sols_html:
The condition for \(f\) to be continuous is

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x\rightarrow t^-} f(x) &= \lim_{x\rightarrow t^+} f(x)\\ e^{-t}&=2(t+1)\end{aligned}\]

Since both piece of the function are continuous, we can use direct substitution and find \(t\). We must show there exists a solution to the above equation. Equivalently we want to show that the following function \(g(t)\) has a zero

\[\begin{aligned} g(t)=e^{-t}-2(t+1)\end{aligned}\]

Note that \(g\) is continuous since it is constructed from continuous functions. We aim to apply IVT. Observe

\[\begin{aligned} g(0)&=e^0-2<0\\ g(-1)&=e^1-2(-1+1)=e>0\end{aligned}\]

Hence by the IVT there exists \(c \in (-1,0)\) such that \(g(c)=0\). At \(t=c\), we have \(e^{-c} = 2(c+1)\). In turn, this means we have the two one sided limits equalling each other and hence \(f(x)\) will be continuous by choosing \(x=c\).

statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{lr} e^{-x} & \text{if}\quad x < t\\ 2(x+1) & \text{if} \quad x \geq t \end{array} \right.\end{aligned}\]

Explain why there exists a number \(t\) such that \(f\) is continuous.

(Hint: apply the Intermediate Value Theorem to the function \(e^{-t}-2(t+1)\).)
